Here is an English quatrain-form poem that preserves the emotional arc and imagery of the original while reading as a coherent standalone piece. Each stanza is a quatrain (4 lines).

---

**I**

You are the distant road,  
A lamp in mountain mist;  
I walk within your gaze,  
A child the dawn has kissed.  

**II**

You are the moonlit breeze,  
And I your sheltered dream;  
Seen or unseen, our lives  
Flow as a single stream.  

**III**

I’ll love the world you loved,  
Seek smiles you longed to see;  
Your hand I reach to hold—  
Lead tomorrow into me.  

**IV**

If you knew bitter nights  
Before my days grew sweet,  
I’ll live to be your wish,  
Brave, unbowed, and complete.  

**V**

You are the rivered years,  
The sky where sparks ascend;  
I look to you in song—  
My origin and end.  

**VI**

All roads the earth can write  
Will cross your form again;  
In every path I choose,  
Your footsteps still remain.  

**VII**

I’ll dream the dreams you dreamt,  
Will what you willed to stay;  
Walk long the roads you walked—  
Love made in this bright day.  

**VIII**

Where mountains stand unharmed,  
And hearth-fires glow at ease,  
Your longing gazes rest  
On children soft in peace.  

**IX**

I’ll see the worlds you missed,  
Write verses you began;  
Moon on the horizon,  
You stay beside my hand.  

**X**

Clear is our lifelong vow,  
Bright as your youthful face.

parts:
You are the distant road, the lamp in mountain haze;  
I am a wandering child who walks within your eyes.  
Moon-bright and wind-clear, you soften all my days;  
Seen or unseen, my life in your embrace resides.  

I will love this human world because you loved it first;  
I will wish for every smile your longing held dear.  
Clutching your hand, I stumble toward the breaking dawn—  
Lead me into tomorrow, though my steps shake with fear.  

If you once drank the bitter so I might taste the sweet,  
I will live my every day to answer your desire.  
May nothing be in vain—let me go forth, unafraid,  
Honouring this shining age with each small mortal hour.  

You are the river of years, the sky with sparks ablaze;  
I am the one who looks up and turns your name to song.  
You are where I have come from and where my heart returns;  
All roads beneath the sun will meet your love ere long.  

Mountains and rivers stand whole, the fireworks soft and plain;  
Just as you once hoped, you gaze on this untroubled land.  
Children sleep safe in their dreams, as you so deeply loved;  
Peace brushes common nights like blessing from your hand.  

I will dream the dream you dreamed of families whole again;  
I will wish the wish you wished for love that does not end.  
I will walk the road you walked, through distance, dust and rain—  
Loving you in this way, more than child and more than friend.  

I will see the unseen worlds your eyes ran out of time;  
I will write the unwritten lines your heart had meant to send.  
Moon at the edge of the sky, your presence in my mind—  
You live beside me always, my first and final friend.  

I pledge a life kept clear with you, transparent and serene,  
As clear as once your youthful face in morning’s quiet light.  
Through every changing year, may my heart stay steady, true,  
So the promise made with you remains forever bright.
